description.narrative:
WLPs mission is to transform power relations and promote justice, equality, peace, and sustainable development by strengthening the feminist movement. WLP's vision is "Democratic and peaceful societies that embrace pluralism and tolerance and are governed by gender-equitable norms, legislation, and policies that translate into equal rights and equal levels of participation and decision-making for women and men in the family, community, and politics."
The interventions overall objective is to empower women to become active citizens and participatory leaders in achieving legal equality, economic justice, security and political participation through capacity building, awareness raising, advocacy and policy work.

Women’s Learning Partnership for Rights, Development, and Peace (WLP) is an international women’s rights organization comprised of a partnership of 20 autonomous women’s rights organizations, primarily from transitioning and developing societies with WLP’s secretariat located in Maryland, USA. WLP’s mission is to transform power relations and promote justice, equality, peace, and sustainable development by strengthening the feminist movement. This is done through curriculum and resource development, training, capacity development, advocacy and movement building while promoting and sustaining leadership that is participatory and replicable. WLP's overall objective is to empower women to become active citizens and effective participatory leaders and to build communities of shared values of social and political change to achieve legal equality, economic justice, security and political participation through advocacy and movement building.
Sida has funded WLP with core support from 2015. Through curriculum development, training, civil society strengthening, women’s human rights advocacy and movement building, WLP has expanded partners’ international, regional, and local leadership, raised public awareness on democracy and women’s rights, strengthened democratic development and political participation by training more than 22,000 emerging leaders, and achieved commendable results through partners’ advocacy and activism.
WLP submitted an application to Sida for core support of 36 000 000 SEK for a four-year time-frame (2018-2022) on 27 March, 2018. The intervention will focus on capacity development of its partners, women and girls through training programs; produce and promote feminist research from the Global South; participate in and support women’s organisations’ advocacy and networking activities; preserve women’s movement history though documentation of the women’s movement; and expand WLP’s international outreach for long-term sustainability. Additionally, WLP will expand its program in four new directions in response to external factors shaping the rights of women globally: i) empowering refugee women, ii) reforming family law, iii) promoting human security, and iv) strengthening the capacity of women's civil society organisations.
The intervention's total budget for 1 July 2018 to 30 June 2022 is approximately 90 000 000 SEK, out of which WLP has secured funding of approximately 5 870 000 SEK (663 000 USD). Several of WLP's donors provide short term support which is expected to be renewed on a yearly basis. The support from Sida accounts for approximately 40% of the organization's total budget during the 4 year intervention period.

Women’s Learning Partnership for Rights, Development, and Peace (WLP) är en koalition bestående av 20 autonoma kvinnorättsorganisationer med ett sekretariat i Bethesda, USA. WLP är en organisation som värdesätter lokalt ägarskap och mångfald i sina partnerskap. Organisationen agerar utifrån ett rättighetsperspektiv och kombinerar kontextbaserad kapacitetsutveckling med forskning och policyutveckling. WLP har också ett starkt fokus på Syd-Syd samarbete som en central komponent i sitt demokrati och jämställdhetsarbete.
WLP inkom 27 mars 2018 med en ansökan till Sida om fortsatt kärnstöd om 36 000 000 SEK för perioden 1 juli 2018 till 30 juni 2022. Insatsen syftar till att stödja kapacitetsutveckling av sina partnerorganisationer, kvinnor och flickor; främja feministisk forskning i det globala Syd; stödja kvinnoorganisationers påverkansarbete och nätverk; dokumentera kvinnorörelsens historia med fokus på Syd; samt stärka WLPs uppdrag och hållbarhet. Dessutom planerar WLP att utöka sitt arbete i fyra nya riktningar: i) stödja flyktingkvinnor genom att stärka deras kapacitet och ledarskap, ii) reform av loka familjelagstiftning, iii) främja mänsklig säkerhet, och iv) stärka kvinnorättsorganisationers kapacitet.
Utvecklingsinsatsens totala budget för perioden 1 juli 2018 till 30 juni 2022 är ca 90 000 000 SEK av vilka WLPs givare har bekräftat stöd om cirka 5 870 000 SEK (663 000 USD). Flera av WLPs givare ger ett-åriga stöd vilka förväntas förnyas på årlig basis. Stödet från Sida står för cirka 40% av organisationens totala budget under de 4 år som Sidas stöd omfattar, förutsätt att övriga givares bidrag blir enligt plan.

sector.narrative: Women’s rights organisations and movements, and government institutions

tag.narrative: 16.7 - Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.

title.narrative: Cover letter to Grant Agreement UNDAP II Rwanda
Grant agreement between Sida and Womens learning partnership 2018-2022

description.narrative:
The core activities funded by Sida include curriculum and resource development, training, civil society strengthening, advocacy, and movement building. WLP and their 20 partner organisations are mobilizing communities, organizations, activists, policymakers, and other stakeholders at local, national, regional, and international levels on a range of human rights initiatives. WLPs programs and learning materials are helping to increase women's potential to participate as active citizens to demand their rights and implement change, including through increased use of social media.
The contexts in which WLP and the partners work are often challenging and present both political and organizational risks. Over the past years, nearly all of WLPs partners have been impacted by the global refugee crises. There has been progress on women's rights in many countries, but it has been slow and uneven. Activists have worked diligently to defend the hard-won gains of the past decades. In many of WLP's partner countries, national governments are limiting space and resources for civil society actors. This presents organizational risks for WLP partners, as there are fewer funding opportunities for civil society organizations and increasing bureaucratic barriers to operation.
Despite these challenges, WLP partners continue to find entry points for reform and opportunities to advance women's human rights. Building on local knowledge, partners contextualize WLP resources and methodology to train women, men, and youth to be better advocates for change. Leveraging their international and national networks, WLP partners work to hold governments, policymakers, and institutions accountable for their actions on gender equality.
Worldwide, partners have reported increased public awareness about the issues they work on, as well as increased engagement from civil society organizations in advocacy campaigns. During 2020/2021 WLP activities reached over 5,000 people in 40 countries and WLP adapted their programming aimed at strengthening civil society organizations to current COVID-19 realities. The Partnership also engaged with international institutions most notably the African Union, the CEDAW Committee, the UN Commission on Human Rights, UN Women, and the Commission on the Status of Women. In addition to continuing WLPs core program, WLP has also pursued new directions the last year with empowering refugee women, reforming family laws to end gender-based violence (GBV), promoting human security, and strengthening women's civil society organizations. As an example, WLP was successful in advocating for policies to ensure greater gender inclusion in land rights across Africa and for laws addressing the inequitable burden of environmental degradation on vulnerable populations around the world. WLP partners successfully championed women's rights to land in Morocco and women's demands for environmental policy changes in Kyrgyzstan.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
